updated_data <- updated_data %>%
        rename(ride_type = rideable_type, customer_type = member_casual)
glimpse(updated_data)
source.10a1c476:
# As we have time in the format of dttm, we can not use it to make calculations about the ride time
# therefore we have to convert it into the format which can be used for calculations and for analysis.

# Column for the trip starting year.
updated_data$year <- format(as.Date(updated_data$started_at),"%Y")

# Column for the trip starting month.
updated_data$month <- format(as.Date(updated_data$started_at),"%m")

# Column for the trip starting day.
updated_data$day <- format(as.Date(updated_data$started_at),"%d")

# Column for the day of the week.
updated_data$day_of_the_week <- format(as.Date(updated_data$started_at),"%A")
source.dc41019d:
# Checking out the newly created columns
head(updated_data,5)
source.498285e4:
# Calculating the trip length in seconds.
updated_data$trip_length <- difftime(updated_data$ended_at, updated_data$started_at)

head(updated_data,5)
source.6802027a:
# Converting trip_length to numbers so that we can perform calculations on it.
updated_data$trip_length <- as.numeric(as.character(updated_data$trip_length))
glimpse(updated_data)

nrow(subset(updated_data, start_station_name %like% "HQ"))
nrow(subset(updated_data, start_station_name %like% "TEST"))
nrow(subset(updated_data, start_station_name %like% "test"))

source.d931fea4:
# In the above table we notice that the days of the week are not in order, so we will arrange them in order
updated_data_v3$day_of_the_week <- ordered(updated_data_v3$day_of_the_week, levels=c("Sunday", "Monday", "Tuesday", "Wednesday", "Thursday", "Friday", "Saturday"))
source.fb11328b:
updated_data_v3 %>%
    group_by(customer_type,day_of_the_week) %>%
    summarise(number_of_rides = n(),average_trip_length = mean(trip_length)) %>%
    arrange(customer_type, desc(number_of_rides))
source.b140ad01:
# Let's visualize the number of rides vs. Day of the week.
updated_data_v3 %>% 
  group_by(customer_type, day_of_the_week) %>% 
  summarise(number_of_rides = n()
            ,average_duration = mean(trip_length)) %>% 
  arrange(customer_type, day_of_the_week)  %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = day_of_the_week, y = number_of_rides, fill = customer_type)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.5, position = position_dodge(width = 0.5)) + labs(title = "No of rides by Customer type vs. Day of the week") +
    scale_y_continuous(labels = function(x) format(x, scientific = FALSE))
source.eeb8e539:
# Let's create a visualization for average duration
updated_data_v3 %>% 
  group_by(customer_type, day_of_the_week) %>% 
  summarise(number_of_rides = n()
            ,average_duration = mean(trip_length)) %>% 
  arrange(customer_type, day_of_the_week)  %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = day_of_the_week, y = average_duration, fill = customer_type)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.5, position = position_dodge(width = 0.5)) + labs(title = "Average ride duration by Customer type vs. Day of the week") +
    scale_y_continuous(labels = function(x) format(x, scientific = FALSE))
source.f7248ac2:
# Let's visualize the number of rides by customer type vs. month
updated_data_v3 %>% 
  group_by(customer_type, month) %>% 
  summarise(number_of_rides = n()
            ,average_duration = mean(trip_length)) %>% 
  arrange(customer_type, month)  %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = month, y = number_of_rides, fill = customer_type)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.5, position = position_dodge(width = 0.5)) + labs(title = "No of rides by Customer type vs. Month") +
    scale_y_continuous(labels = function(x) format(x, scientific = FALSE))
source.c00e2ed1:
# Let's visualize the average duration vs. ride type
updated_data_v3 %>% 
  group_by(customer_type, ride_type) %>% 
  summarise(number_of_rides = n()
            ,average_duration = mean(trip_length)) %>% 
  arrange(customer_type, ride_type)  %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = ride_type, y = average_duration, fill = customer_type)) +
  geom_col(width = 0.5, position = position_dodge(width = 0.5)) + labs(title = "Average ride duration vs. Ride type") +
    scale_y_continuous(labels = function(x) format(x, scientific = FALSE))
source.87330189:
exported_data <- aggregate(updated_data_v3$trip_length ~ updated_data_v3$customer_type + updated_data_v3$day_of_the_week, FUN = mean)
write_csv(exported_data, "exported data.csv")
source.e8135e37: The average trip duration for docked bike is the highest followed by classic bike and then electric bike for both of the customers which shows that docked bike is the favorite option among the casual as well as the member customer types. Also the average duration for docked bike for the members is the highest among all of the options and the casual customers indicating and reinforcing the implication that the members use rides mostly for daily commute and those rides are mostly docked bikes.
source.a2f56c03: Using the Head function to inspect the data for initial 10 columns to get an idea of any inconsistancy among the data sets.
source.2c589706:
#Capstone Project: Cyclistic BIKE-SHARE

Completed on: 06/10/2021

By: Ramana Reddy Kota

##**Introduction**
This case study is the part of the **Google Data Analytics Professional Certificate** offered as the 8th and the last module to help students demonstrate their knowledge and skills gained during the whole course. This is also directed towards the students to make it the part of their online portfolio and show it to prospective employers.

##**Scenario**
Cyclistic is a bike-share company in Chicago. The director of marketing believes the company’s future success depends on maximizing the number of annual memberships. Cyclistic finance analysts have found that the annual members are much more profitable than casual riders. Now the marketing team is aimed at converting casual riders to annual members. But in order to do so, the marketing analyst team needs to better understand how annual members and casual riders differ and what can be done in order to achieve their goal.

##**Business Task**
The business task which is given to me is, how do annual members and casual riders use Cyclistic bikes differently?

##**Data Sources**
The data has been provided by Motivate International Inc. under this license. Data is a collection of 12 months bike trips data from June 2020 to May 2021. Size of the data is approximately 700mb which is difficult to work on in spreadsheet softwares as well as SQL. The most suitable option for this analysis is the use of R which can both handle this big data and also provide powerful visualizations too.
source.7ad10dbe:
**Key Findings**
The average use of rides stay the same for members through out the week.
The average use of rides is stay low during the week for casuals but become high during the weekends.
The average trip duration for casuals remain high at any day of the week where as it remains low but almost constant for the members during the week.
The no. of rides taken by casuals decrease significantly during the winters which is also true for the members but it decreases at a much lower rate for them.
The use of docked bike is much more than the classic bike and the electric bike for the members whereas the casuals use all of the bikes almost equally without a significant difference between any of them.

source.b313e139: Creating a .csv file for further use for analysis in Excel, Tableau or other tools.
source.db0c2001: Data in the start_station_id & end_station_id columns of june20, july20, aug20, sep20, oct20, nov20 is inconsistent with the remaining dataframes because the data type in these columns is double where as data type in the similar columns of other dataframes is character. So in order to make data consistent we have to change the data type of doubles into characters as well. The reason for this and not the other way around is because if we convert characters into doubles then there may be a chance where the data will be truncated but if we convert doubles into characters then the data will not be harmed.
source.27de9041: Reading and Assigning 12 Months Trip Data to new variables
source.0cb29944: Now we have cleaned the data by removing rows which have faulty data so now we do not need those columns for Data Analysis. Removing those columns in order to make the data frame smaller and to use less resources.
source.f88a3ae8: Using rbind function to merge different data sets into a single file
source.d56e2af4: **Suggestions** based on the findings above, I think that we should device a strategy in which the casuals are incentivised and encouraged to use the bikes through out the week. Also for them the price difference between all types of bikes should be kept at a minimum so that they continue to use them equally and when they use them for a longer period of time due to incentives they would be forced to think of becoming an annual member.
source.030267df: The difference between casual and member type customers is low during the weekends where the number of rides taken by casuals is greater than members but during the week days the difference between both of the customer types is relatively high where the members have considerably greater number of rides than the casuals. This can mean that the casuals use the rides mainly for recreational purposes whereas the members use it both for commuting to their work/study places and also for recreation on weekends. Also the average usage of rides by the members stay the same through out the week whereas the average usage of rides by the casuals stay on the low during the week days while become high during the weekend.
source.f720c0e1: The difference between the average ride duration of casuals and the members remains high through out the week. If we look at the average trip duration for members, it stays almost constant through out the week which can also mean that the members having access to the rides every day only use the rides for selected period of time daily whereas the casuals when rent the ride for any day, they spend a lot of time using the rides. It can also imply that the casuals who use the rides each day are mostly new customers otherwise they would go for a membership.
source.3cd12b48: #**Combining the data into a single file**
source.345229b2: The number of rows before and after the merge of the data frames are equal which means that the data is merged successfully.
source.c50dee3e: The number of rides for both the members as well as casuals show no particular pattern through out the year but one thing which can be concluded from the graph is that the no. of rides by the casual customers are low in quantity during the winters in the months of Jan, Feb, Mar as well as Nov and Dec and continue to rise towards the start of summers and decline during the start of winters. This is also true in the case of members as well but the overall amount of number of rides is high as compared to casuals.
